Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i just added up the prior 12 solvetimes

Author: zawy#5864
Content: Oh, sorry, I'm looking at block 330

Author: zawy#5864
Content: Also, the trigger is W+1 < T\*num/den

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i thought that seemed too slow to catch the on/off miners

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: W of 3 needs 4 solvtimes?

Author: zawy#5864
Content: Yes, that's what I thought we did

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: to be in 30 seconds?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so it is 8x to trigger

Author: zawy#5864
Content: yes

Author: zawy#5864
Content: no

Author: zawy#5864
Content: it's a tricky possion effect......

Author: zawy#5864
Content: The hashrate of a blockchain is 2^256/avg(target) * T / (sum N solvetimes)  * (N-1)

Author: zawy#5864
Content: The average(1/avgSolvetime) is not the same as avgSolvetime because poisson distribution is not symmetrical

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i understand i made it a bit more trigger happy, but the ave blocktime is still on track and this makes it harder to do on/off mining

Author: zawy#5864
Content: Yeah, it did seem a little more trigger happy.  What you have might be OK, but the thing to do is to raise the 0.5%.    330 looks like a good time to trigger, but my math is saying it's pretty sensitive

Author: zawy#5864
Content: So maybe the reason the last blocks are < 60 is because a W=12 window is rolling out the back of your  past setting

Author: zawy#5864
Content: so a short solve time gets discounted

Author: zawy#5864
Content:
In the above eq for hashrate, our W is N-1...in other words
hashrate =  2^256/avg(target) * T / (sum W+1  solvetimes)  * W
We're checking if the Hashrate was unexpectedly high

Author: zawy#5864
Content: 6x in W=3

Author: zawy#5864
Content: But the goal is not to detect 6x with 50% chance per 3 blocks, but to not trigger at > 0..5%

Author: zawy#5864
Content: on accident

Author: zawy#5864
Content: I still can't figure out how 336 and 337 were the last two in the series

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but based on how it behaves, a false positive trigger is really not any disaster

Author: zawy#5864
Content: Triggering on accident too often is not what concerns me, but that it's triggering under logic at the end that does not seem to be based on a weaker trigger. I wonder if it is actually using Digi Shield at that point

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, all 0 means it is digishield (or exp() without RST)

Author: zawy#5864
Content: that means RST is active on 336 and 337 and I can't see why.  It could be a security risk, but in any event it seems  there is room for improvement

Author: Alright#0419
Content:
@jl777c it depends on how the cumulative proof of work is calculated, ie how many easy diff blocks I have to mine to surpass pow of real chain to reorg it. 

Invalidate 7 minutes(or more) worth of blocks, you can now mine at minimum diff because local time - prev blocktime  is >7 minutes. Now mine blocks at prev blocktime+1 and you can mine a lot of consecutive blocks at min diff

Author: Alright#0419
Content: maybe not possible if you're competing with other miners, but if a chain was legitimately stalled for 7 minutes, you can shit out a ton of blocks I believe

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: have you tried just trying to mine a lot of blocks using ASIC when diff is 3?

Content: after a few blocks, diff skyrockets

Content: best you try just normal mining to see how it works first
